Highly effective removal of mercury and lead ions from wastewater by mercaptoamine-functionalised silica-coated magnetic nano-adsorbents: Behaviours and mechanisms
Shuangyou Baoa, Kai Lia, Ping Ninga, Jinhui Pengb, Xu Jina, Lihong Tanga*
aFaculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, YunNan, KunMing, 650500, P. R. China bFaculty of Metallurgical and Energy, Kunming University of Science and Technology, YunNan, KunMing 650500, P. R. China
* Corresponding authors:Lihong Tang Tel:13808733050
E-mail addresses: luckyman@163.com, 64862193@qq.com .
Graphical abstract
Highlights
► Highly effective removal of Hg(II) and Pb(II) ions from wastewater. ►This adsorbent had multiple adsorption sites (sulfur and amine sites) on the surface. ► This adsorbent had better tolerance to low pH for removal of Hg(II). ► This new hybrid material was much cheaper and no secondary pollution. ► This adsorbent shows notable advantages including easy separation and recyclability.
Abstract: A novel hybrid material was fabricated using mercaptoamine-functionalised silica-coated magnetic nanoparticles (MAF-SCMNPs) and was effective in the extraction and recovery of mercury and lead ions from wastewater. The properties of this new magnetic material were
explored using various characterisation and analysis methods. Adsorbent amounts, pH levels and initial concentrations were optimised to
improve removal efficiency. Additionally, kinetics, thermodynamics and adsorption isotherms were investigated to determine the mechanism by
which the fabricated MAF-SCMNPs adsorb heavy metal ions. The results revealed that MAF-SCMNPs were acid-resistant. Sorption likely
occurred by chelation through the amine group and ion exchange between heavy metal ions and thiol functional groups on the nanoadsorbent surface. The equilibrium was attained within 120 min, and the adsorption kinetics showed pseudo-second-order (R2 > 0.99). The mercury and
lead adsorption isotherms were in agreement with the Freundlich model, displaying maximum adsorption capacities of 355 and 292 mg/g,
respectively. The maximum adsorptions took place at pH 5-6 and 6-7 for Hg(II) and Pb(II), respectively. The maximum adsorptions were observed
at 10 mg and 12 mg adsorbent quantities for Hg(II) and Pb(II), respectively. The adsorption process was endothermic and spontaneous within the
temperature range of 298-318 K. This work demonstrates a unique magnetic nano-adsorbent for the removal of Hg(II) and Pb(II) from
wastewater.
Keywords: MAF-SCMNPs · mercaptoamine modification · wastewater · mercury and lead ions

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Pollution is a serious issue and can negatively affect the life and health of a population, especially with respect to rapidly developing economies worldwide. A major source of pollution is industrial wastewater, which contain many heavy metals such as mercury, lead, cadmium, nickel, and copper. These heavy metals are considered aquatic biological poisons and as they accumulate up the food chain, these metals can poison the human body and raise serious health concerns [1-2]. Among these toxic metals, mercury and lead ions are the most dangerous contaminants [3], for example, Japan's Minamata Bay accident in 1956. The toxicity of Hg2+ ions, even at notably low concentrations, can cause many serious human health problems, including vision loss, cognitive impairment, motion disorders and dysfunctions of the central nervous system [4]. Therefore, an urgent need to effectively treat wastewater containing heavy metallic ions. Many methods have been adopted, such as ion exchange treatments [5], reverse osmosis filtration [6], chemical precipitation [7], bio-removal [8], electrochemical treatment [9], membrane filtration [10], and solvent extraction [11]. However, these methods have unavoidable disadvantages, such as high cost and complexity, and typically cause secondary pollution. Compared with other treatment methods, adsorption is generally viewed as the most reliable approach to treatment of wastewater containing heavy metals due to convenient operation, low cost, high efficiency and easily regenerated sorbents [12]. The preparation of adsorbents is a key component of adsorption technology. Different types of adsorbents have been developed, including activated carbon [13-15], modified silica [16-17] and biosorbents [18-20].
An ideal adsorbent has a large specific surface area and high physical and/or chemical stability [21-22]. A number of studies have focused on the development of high specific surface areas and highly stable adsorbents to increase heavy metal removal efficiencies. For instance, Md et al. [23] synthesised a ligand-immobilised conjugate adsorbent by direct fixation onto silica with dibenzo-24-crown-8 ether. The resultant adsorbent displayed a large specific surface area and large pore volumes and could be used as a potential conjugate adsorbent for selective removal of Cs from wastewater. Ramesh et al. [24] investigated the properties of MgMn-3-300 for phosphate uptake. Certain adsorbents, such as modified silica, activated carbon and modified resins, have relatively high affinity for certain heavy metals but are difficult to separate. To overcome this disadvantage, adsorbents can be combined with magnetic nanomaterials, which offer outstanding properties such as superparamagnetism, ease of recovery, large specific surface areas, and easily modified surfaces. Because of these characteristics, magnetic nanomaterials show great promise for heavy metal removal from wastewater. Magnetic nanoparticles are typically synthesised via cross-linking [25]. The magnetites (Fe3O4) are used commonly as magnetic cores [26] and many methods have been developed for Fe3O4 nanoparticles [27-29]. However, a few drawbacks exist in the handling the metal, including rapid oxidation and aggregation in solution. These factors reduce the uptake capacity of the magnetic nanoparticle. To protect magnetic nanoparticles from oxidation and prevent their aggregation in solution, silica shells have been immobilised on the magnetic cores to enhance their chemical stability [30].
Adsorption processes and magnetic separation have been successfully used to remove different types of heavy metal ions (e.g., Pb2+, Hg2+, Zn2+, Cr2+,Cu2+, and Cd2+) from wastewater. Such as, Cu(II) removal using magnetic particles has also been reported, based on amine [31-32] chitosan modification [33-34] or imprinting methods [35], among others [36-37]. Selective removal of Cd (II)/(Zn(II)) mixtures from wastewater using magnetic hydroxyapatite nanoparticles [38] and adsorptions of Pb(II) and Zn(II) using imine-functionalised Fe3O4/SiO2 magnetic nano-adsorbents [39] have also been studied. Adsorbents with thiol or poly(1-vinylimidazole) functionalised superparamagnetic nanoparticles have been suggested as highly selective for adsorption of Hg(II) [40-41]. However, the adsorption of mercury and lead are remain scarce in the current studies. New functional groups with good selectivity, high affinity, and satisfactory removal of heavy metal ions from wastewater have recently been developed.
In this study, (3-aminopropyl) trimethoxysilane and chloromethyl thiirane were used as surface modification reagents on silica-coated magnetic nanoparticles (SCMNPs) to obtain new mercaptoamine-functionalised
silica-coated magnetic nanoparticles (MAF-SCMNPs) for effective removal of Hg(II) or Pb(II) ions from wastewater. This adsorbent had multiple adsorption sites on nanoadsorbent surfaces, the presence of multiple adsorption sites (i.e., sulphur and amine sites) can significantly enhance the interactions between adsorbent and heavy metal ions. Furthermore, this material has several advantages, including low cost, easy separation, recyclability and an environmentally friendly process that does not secondary pollution. The as-prepared nano-sorbents were characterised by TEM, FTIR, XPS, BET, and XRD, and their magnetic properties and other parameters that influence
adsorption efficiency were also studied. The influence of experimental conditions such as pH value, metal ion concentration, contact time, and regeneration of the composites on the heavy metal ion adsorption capacity of the prepared nanoparticles were also investigated. Additionally, the sorption and mechanism behaviours of MAF-SCMNPs for Pb(II) and Hg(II) were investigated using XPS and FTIR.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of MAF-SCMNPs
sections.text:
The Fe3O4 particles were synthesised by conventional co-precipitation methods as previously reported [38]. The Fe3O4 coated SiO2 nanoparticles were prepared using a procedure developed by Bao et al. [42]. Activated silica-coated magnetic nanoparticles (SCMNPs) were dispersed in 100 mL of toluene with 30 min sonication, and 2 mL of (3-aminopropyl) trimethoxysilane and several grains of zeolite were added. The suspension was refluxed at 110 ℃ under continuous mechanical stirring for 24 h. Subsequently, the resultant amino-functionalised silica-coated magnetic nanoparticles (AF-SCMNPs) were collected using powerful magnets, washed with ethanol several times, and then dried under vacuum at 50 ℃ for 12 h prior to use.
The AF-SCMNPs were dispersed in 50 mL of dioxane with 30 min sonication. Subsequently, 1 mL of hydrochloric acid (25 wt.%) was added to the mixture. The suspension was cooled in an ice bath (2-5 ℃), and 2 mL of chloromethyl thiirane (prepared by reacting epoxy chloropropane with thiourea) was added dropwise into the suspension under continuous mechanical stirring and cooling. The mixture was removed from the ice bath when gelation was observed. Subsequently, the temperature of the mixture was slowly increased to 70 ℃ under continuous mechanical stirring. After 12 h, the resulting nanoparticles were collected, washed with water and ethanol several times to remove nonmagnetic byproducts, and dried under vacuum at 50 ℃ for 12 h. This MAF-SCMNP fabrication process is shown in Scheme 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Adsorbent characterisation
sections.text: Hydrogen potential values were measured using a pH meter (MP511, China). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using 200 W Mg radiation on a PHI-5500 electron spectrometer. Vacuum-dried powder samples were studied using X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Phillips PW 1730/10). Magnetisation measurements were obtained from a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) with a maximum magnetic field of 10 kOe. The size and shape of the magnetic nanoparticles were investigated with transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Jeol JEM 2010). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was performed on KBr pellets. Powdered samples were inspected using diffuse-reflectance FTIR (DRIFT) spectroscopy with a Nicolet MagnaIR760 spectrometer. The specific surface area was measured by N2 adsorption using the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) method.

sections.heading: 2.3. Batch adsorption experiments
sections.text:
To determine the ability of the composite nanoparticles to adsorb heavy metals, a series of adsorption experiments was performed in conical flasks under 180 rpm shaking at 25°C (unless otherwise specified). To study the effects of pH, 50 mL solutions of 50 mg/L metal ions (Hg2+ and Pb2+) from pH 2-8 were mixed with 10 mg or 12 mg (for
Hg(II) and Pb(II) adsorption, respectively) of magnetic nano-adsorbents for 2 h. These mixtures were continuously shaken on a platform table to ensure sufficient interaction between the MAF-SCMNPs and the metal ions. The solution pH was adjusted by adding 0.1 mol/L HCl or 0.1 mol/L NH3·H2O, and the pH levels of the mixtures were measured using a pH meter. The effects of adsorbent dose were also studied by dispersing 2 mg to 20 mg of adsorbents in 50 mL of 50 mg/L metal ions (Hg2+ and Pb2+) in conical flasks under continuous shaking at 25°C for 2 h. After equilibrium was reached, the conical flasks were placed on a permanent magnet (Nd–Fe–B) for 5 min to separate the magnetic nano-adsorbents from the wastewater solution. The initial and final concentrations of the Hg(II) or Pb(II) ions were measured using inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES).

sections.heading: 3.1. Properties of prepared magnetic adsorbents
sections.text:
Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Fig. 1) were applied to determine the crystalline structure of the nanoparticles. The observed relatively strong reflection peaks at 2θ = 30.1◦, 35.5◦, 43.1◦, 53.4◦, 57.0◦, 62.6◦ and 74.3◦ were ascribed to the (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (4 0 0), (4 2 2), (5 1 1), (4 4 0) and (5 5 3) planes of Fe3O4, which match well with the database of magnetite in the JCPDS (JCPDS Card: 19-629) file. This indicated that the Fe3O4 crystal had a highly crystalline cubic spinel structure. A broad, low intensity diffraction peak from 20-30◦ is also shown in Fig. 1b and is attributed to the diffusion peak of the amorphous silica surrounding the Fe3O4 core. The characteristic peaks of Fe3O4/SiO2 and Fe3O4/SiO2/ligand were also observed at the same position, showing the stability of the crystalline structure of magnetite after silica coating and mercaptoamine functionalization.
The average crystallite size of nanoparticles were calculated from the XRD pattern by means of Scherrer’s equation (D = Kλ/βcosθ), where D is the particle size of the crystal, β is the width of the XRD peak at half-height, θ is the diffraction angle, λ is the X-ray wavelength (1.5406 Å for Cu Kα) and K is the so-called shape factor, here, K=0.9 is chosen for spherical shape. The mean crystallite size calculated using this formula is about 11.8 nm for Fe3O4 NPs, comparing with the result measured from the TEM images (80 nm), it was found that there were great differences. This is because X-ray diffraction gives the information of single crystalline. On the other hand, TEM gives the complete picture of the after the aggregation. After silica-coating and mercaptoamine functionalization, the particle sizes of the magnetite nanoparticles were 12.3 and 13.6 nm for SCMNPs and MAF-SCMNPs, respectively.
Hysteresis loops were obtained using a vibrating sample magnetometer to detect the magnetic properties of the materials. As shown in Fig. 2, the corresponding magnetisations of Fe3O4 NPs, SCMNPs, AF-SCMNPs, and MAF-SCMNPs increased as the magnetic fields increased in strength. The magnetisation saturation levels were 50.9, 41.7, 39.2 and 33.4 emu·g-1 for Fe3O4 NPs, SCMNPs, AF-SCMNPs and MAF-SCMNPs, respectively. These decreases were attributed to the amounts of nonmagnetic silica, (3-aminopropyl) trimethoxysilane and chloromethyl thiirane deposited on the Fe3O4 NPs. Coercivity and remanence were not observed, indicating that these magnetic nanoparticles were superparamagnetic. Although the saturation magnetisation value of the MAF-SCMNPs was lower than those of the Fe3O4 NPs, SCMNPs and AF-SCMNPs, complete magnetic separation of the heavy metals on the MAF-SCMNPs was achieved after only a 5 min application of magnets in the wastewater solutions (see the lower and near insets of Fig. 2). The MAF-SCMNPs still displayed high levels of magnetisation, indicating promising applications for adsorption and separation.
The TEM images of the (a) Fe3O4 NPs, (b) SCMNPs, and (c) MAF-SCMNPs are compared and shown in Fig. 3. As displayed in Fig. 3(a), the Fe3O4 nanoparticles tended to aggregate, and the average diameter of the Fe3O4 nanoparticles was approximately 80 nm. The observed aggregation might be attributed to the small size and the preferential demand for reduction of the interfacial energy of the nanoparticles. Fig. 3(b) further shows that silica structures are observed, and the black colour surrounding the Fe3O4 NPs is indicative of the SiO2 shell. This demonstrated that the Fe3O4 cores were successfully embedded in silica shells. Furthermore, the SCMNPs were observed as being wrapped in a thin layer of translucent polymer coat.
The BET specific surface area of the Fe3O4 NPs was determined to be 33.2 m 2/g. After deposition of SiO2 on the Fe3O4 NPs, the surface area significantly increased to 93.2 m 2/g. After surface modification with mercaptoamine, the specific surface area of the resultant MAF-SCMNPs was 71.9 m2/g. This demonstrated that the pores of the SiO2 shell were partially covered by the mercaptoamine molecules.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Sorption kinetics
sections.text: The rate of uptake is one of the most significant characteristics of an adsorbent. The uptake kinetics of mercury and lead using MAF-SCMNPs are shown in Fig. 4A. The uptake rates of mercury and lead were rapidly enhanced in the early phases of the process. After 2 h, the metal ion adsorptions remained nearly unchanged, showing that the adsorption processes were at equilibrium. Therefore, the contact time of 2 h was sufficient and was used in subsequent batch experiments. The corresponding kinetic parameters from the pseudo-second-order kinetics are summarised in Table 1, and the plots of the kinetic model are displayed in Figs. 4B and C. As shown in Table 1, the correlation coefficient (R2) values for the second-order kinetic model were above 0.942, which are higher than that of the pseudo-first-order model (below 0.800). Furthermore, the experimental values (qe, exp) showed better agreement with the anticipated results calculated (qe, cal) by the pseudo-second-order model than with those calculated by the pseudo-first-order model. These results indicated that the pseudo-second-order model better described the uptake process of Hg(II) and Pb(II) by MAF-SCMNPs.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Sorption isotherms
sections.text:
The equilibrium Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm data for mercury and lead are shown in Fig. 5. Fig. 5A shows the Langmuir adsorption isotherms. The maximum sorption capacities for mercury and lead ions were calculated using the Langmuir equation and were 355 and 292 mg/g, respectively, values that are relatively high compared with reported in the literature [41]. It was revealed that the MAF-SCMNP adsorbent exhibited a high uptake capacity for mercury and lead. Fig. 5B shows the Freundlich adsorption isotherms.
Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm parameters were calculated and are summarised in Table 2. Based on the correlation coefficients (R2), the experimental data fit the Freundlich model better than the Langmuir model, demonstrating that mercury and lead adsorption on MAF-SCMNPs can be considered multilayer adsorption processes.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Effects of pH
sections.text:
The adsorption of mercury and lead on MAF-SCMNPs was investigated over a pH range of 2.0-8.0. The initial mercury and lead concentrations were 50.0 mg/L. The magnetic nano-adsorbents were separated from wastewater by a magnet (Nd–Fe–B) after equilibrium was reached at 25 ± 1 ℃ after 2 h. Fig. 6 presents the relationships between the uptake of heavy metals by the MAF-SCMNPs and the initial pH. The adsorption of mercury and lead increased with increasing initial pH of the sorption solution. The maximum mercury adsorption was observed at pH 5-6, whereas the
maximum uptake was observed at pH 6-7 for lead. Higher initial pH values were avoided to prevent precipitation of hydroxides. However, the MAF-SCMNPs exhibited a high uptake capacity for mercury (greater than 120 mg/g) at low pH, which might be attributed to a greater affinity between mercury and the sorbent than that between H+ and the sorbent. At lower pH values, the significantly reduced adsorption was attributed to competition between H+ and Pb(II) for adsorption sites on MAF-SCMNP surfaces. Overall, the MAF-SCMNPs sorbents effectively eliminated heavy metal ions from neutral solutions and had better tolerance to low pH. The removal efficiencies of MAF-SCMNPs from pH 2-6 were greater for Hg2+ than Pb2+. This could be explained by hard and soft acid base theory, wherein hard acids prefer to coordinate with hard bases and soft acids with soft bases [43]. Hg is considered softer than Pb [44].

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Effects of temperature and thermodynamic parameters
sections.text:

The sorption of metal on MAF-SCMNPs was investigated at 298-318 K, and other experimental conditions constant were maintained constant. The thermodynamic parameters from the fitted line are summarised in Table 3. The Gibbs free energy decreased from -10.98 kJ/mol to -12.65 kJ/mol or from -10.18 kJ/mol to -11.24 kJ/mol as the temperature increased from 298 to 318 K. This showed that the adsorption process at higher temperatures was more spontaneous due to the enlarged pore sizes and correspondingly increased surface area available for adsorption. This could also be due to the increased mobility of Hg(II) and Pb(II) at increased temperatures [45]. Changes in standard free energy widely vary for physical adsorptions and range from −20 to 0 kJ/mol, whereas changes in standard free energy vary even more widely for chemical adsorptions, from −80 to −400 kJ/mol [46].Thus, the examined process might be a physical-chemical adsorption. The changes in enthalpy (△Ho) and entropy (△So) of the adsorptions were obtained and are shown in Table 3. The positive values of △So indicated increased randomness during uptake of Hg(II) and Pb(II) in wastewater by the MAF-SCMNPs.

sections.heading: 3.2.5. Effects of adsorbent amount
sections.text:
The effects of adsorbent amount on adsorption rate were examined using different amounts of adsorbents from 2 to 20 mg (Fig. 7). As shown in Fig. 7, the amounts of mercury and lead by the MAF-SCMNPs sharply increased as the sorbent dose increased from 2 to 10 mg and from 2 to 12 mg for mercury and lead, respectively. This phenomenon was likely due to increased numbers of vacant adsorption sites and increased surface area availability. When the amounts of adsorbents were increased to 10 mg and 12 mg for mercury and lead, the adsorption amounts reached maximums. However, the adsorption capacity decreased as the adsorbent dosage increased from 10 to 20 mg and from 12 to 20 mg due to reduced available surface area and reduced unoccupied active sites. Moreover, large doses
might result in adsorbent aggregation [47]. Therefore, high adsorbent dosages did not enhance adsorption capacities. Thus, 10 mg and 12 mg for mercury and lead, respectively, were chosen as the optimum adsorbent doses for further experiments.

sections.heading: 3.2.6. Adsorption mechanism
sections.text:
FTIR spectroscopy was used to elucidate the interaction mechanisms between the metal ions and the adsorbents.
Fig. 8 shows the FTIR spectra of the MAF-SCMNPs before and after sorption of Hg(II) and Pb(II). The broad adsorption band from 3100-3700 cm−1 can be attributed to the stretching vibration of O-H and N-H in the MAF-SCMNPs [48]. The absorption peaks located at 2925 cm-1 can be assigned to -CH anti-symmetric stretching vibrations in -CH and -CH2. Compared with the FTIR spectrum of MAF-SCMNPs in Fig. 8(a), the FTIR spectra of MAF-SCMNPs-Hg and MAF-SCMNPs-Pb in Figs. 8(b) and 8(c) shows the loss of a peak at 1633 cm-1 and the appearance of a new peak at 1637 cm-1. The peak at 1637 cm-1 can be attributed to the vibration of MAF-SCMNP surface nitrogen atoms, which form coordination bonds with the heavy metal ions [49]. These changes in the spectra were likely due to the adsorption of mercury and lead ions onto the imine (–C-NH–) groups on the MAF-SCMNP surfaces. The characteristic peaks located at 2538 cm-1 can be ascribed to S-H stretches of the MAF-SCMNPs. These peaks are typically quite weak and convoluted due to the aggregation of mercapto groups within the surface monolayer and hydrogen binding effects [50]. Generally, the S-H stretching band is characteristically weak and cannot be detected in the spectra of dilute solutions [51]. After uptake of the Hg(II) and Pb(II) ions, the disappearances of the absorption peaks at 2538 cm-1 were mainly attributed to ion exchanges between the Hg(II) and Pb(II) ions and the thiol functional groups on the nanoadsorbent surfaces. Additionally, after Pb(II) adsorption, a new characteristic peak at 1384 cm−1 was observed and is attributed to NO2 stretching vibrations in NO3 − ions [52]. NO3 − ions on the MAF-SCMNP surface balance the electrical charges of the adsorbed Pb(II) ions. These changes are due to the chelation properties of amine groups and the ion exchange between heavy metal ions and thiol functional groups on the nanoadsorbent surfaces.
To further verify the findings from the FTIR spectra, XPS spectra of the MAF-SCMNPs before and after adsorption were examined and are shown in Fig. 9. As observed in the broad scans in Fig. 9(a)-(c), in addition to the characteristic peaks of C 1s (285 eV), N 1s (399 eV), O 1s (531 eV) and S 2p (163 eV) for the MAF-SCMNPs, Hg (101.8 eV) and Pb (138.1 eV) peaks were clearly observed for MAF-SCMNPs-Hg and MAF-SCMNPs-Pb, respectively. These XPS results confirm that the heavy metal ions (Hg2+ and Pb2+) could be loaded onto the MAF-SCMNP surface. To verify the FTIR assay finding that the adsorptions of the Hg2+ or Pb2+ ions occurred via the formation of coordination bonds between the heavy metal ions and N and/or S atoms on the nano-adsorbent surfaces, the binding energies for N 1s and S 2p in the MAF-SCMNPs, MAF-SCMNPs-Hg and MAF-SCMNPs-Pb spectra are compared in Figs. 9(a)-(c). The peaks at 399.0 and 401.1 eV are assigned to N 1s (Fig. 9(a)) of the N atoms in neutral (NH) and protonated (NH+) amines, respectively, [53] on the nano-adsorbent surfaces. After adsorption of mercury or lead by the MAF-SCMNPs, new peaks were observed in the N 1s spectra of MAF-SCMNPs-Hg (Fig. 9(b)) and MAF-SCMNPs-Pb (Fig. 9(c)). Furthermore, new peaks at 400.2 eV were observed for the MAF-SCMNPs with adsorbed heavy metal ions, as shown in Figs. 9(b-c). This result was mainly attributed to the formation of N–Hg(II) and N–Pb(II) complexes, wherein a lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom was donated to a heavy metal ion, and as a consequence, the electron cloud density surrounding the N atom was reduced, leading to a higher BE peak. The other new peaks 406.3 eV and 167.6 eV were attributed to the N atom in nitrate ions and the sulphur atom in sulphate ions, respectively [54-55]. Therefore, the XPS spectra provided evidence of Pb and Hg binding to nitrogen atoms and the existence of nitrate ions on the surfaces of MAF-SCMNPs-Pb, in agreement with the FTIR spectroscopy findings. The XPS spectra of S 2p on MAF-SCMNPs nano-adsorbent before and after the adsorption of Hg(II) and Pb(II) are shown in Figs. 9(a-c). Based
on previous reports, the typical S 2p3/2 BE for bound thiols is less than 163 eV and for unbound thiols is between 163 and 164 eV. After the adsorptions of Hg(II) and Pb(II), the maximum position of the peak at 163.1 eV shifted from 163.1 to 161.8 eV or from 163.1 to 161.9, consistent with prior reports on heavy metal ions binding to sulphur atoms [56-57]. Therefore, the XPS N 1s and S 2p spectra in Figs. 9(a–c) verified the FTIR spectroscopy results wherein mercury and lead ions were observed to adsorb onto the surfaces of the MAF-SCMNPs by forming coordination bonds with surface sulphur and nitrogen atoms.
According to the mechanism analysis above, a proposed uptake mechanism for Hg(II) or Pb(II) on MAF-SCMNPs
is shown in Scheme 2.

sections.heading: 3.3. Comparison with other magnetic sorbents
sections.text: Table 4 compares the maximum capacity of the prepared MAF-SCMNPs with those of other adsobents reported in the literature for Hg2+ and Pb2+ adsorption. MAF-SCMNPs have relatively higher uptake capacities than the other adsorbents, which might be attributed to the multifunctional chelation properties of the amine and thiol functional groups and the higher numbers of active sites for the mercury and lead ions. Although some adsorbents have relatively high affinity for certain heavy metals, but they do not offer the possibility of magnetic separation. The high uptake capacity and magnetic properties of the functional MAF-SCMNPs components towards Hg(II) and Pb(II) ions indicated that the nanoparticles could be used as potential adsorbents for the removal of Hg(II) and Pb(II) ions from wastewater.

sections.heading: 3.4. Desorption and regeneration experiment
sections.text: Fig. 10 shows the relationship between the uptake capacities of regenerated nano-adsorbents and the number of reuse cycles. The uptake capacity of the nanocomposites sharply decreased after one adsorption-desorption cycle finished. This results might be attributed to the loss of part groups which were not bonded to silica surface tightly in the desorption process, thus the adsorption capacity remained stable in the following reuse. We have repeated the above procedure for five cycles. As shown in Fig. 10, the removal efficiency is slightly reduced in the subsequent cycles. This decrease may be due to some active sites on adsorbents occupied by heavy metal ions could not be completely recovered. However, the adsorption rates remained above 93% after five adsorption–desorption cycles. Therefore, based on practical applications, the MAF-SCMNPs showed satisfactory adsorption performance after regeneration and can potentially be used repeatedly as an economic and efficient adsorbent for the removal of heavy metal ions from wastewaters.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
A new magnetic nanocomposite for the elimination of Hg(II) and Pb(II) ions from wastewater was synthesised by immobilisation of (3-aminopropyl)-triethoxysilane and chloromethyl thiirane on Fe3O4/SiO2 nanoparticles. These magnetic nanoadsorbents can rapidly, efficiently and conveniently remove Hg(II) and Pb(II) ions from wastewater. Additionally, the presence of multiple adsorption sites (i.e., sulphur and amine sites) on the surfaces of the nanoadsorbents can significantly enhance uptake capacities and acid resistance. These improvements are primarily attributed to the chelation property of the amine groups and ion exchange interactions between the heavy metal ions and the thiol functional groups on the nanoadsorbent surface. The results demonstrate that the uptake capacities of the nanoadsorbent for Hg(II) and Pb(II) were consistent with pseudo-second-order kinetic models and the Freundlich adsorption model. The maximum adsorption capacities for Hg(II) and Pb(II) were 355 and 292 mg/g, respectively. Furthermore, thermodynamic studies showed that the adsorption process of the MAF-SCMNPs was endothermic and spontaneous in nature. The maximum adsorptions took place at pH 5–6 and 6-7 for Hg(II) and Pb(II), respectively, and
reached equilibrium within 120 min. The maximum adsorptions were observed at 10 mg and 12 mg adsorbent quantities for Hg(II) and Pb(II), respectively. Overall, these results demonstrated that MAF-SCMNPs are promising adsorbents for the removal of Hg(II) and Pb(II) from wastewater.
